p.paragraphs: Note that, seemingly paradoxically, red and green mix additively to produce yellow, but most of us do not perceive yellow as being both reddish and greenish.
On the other hand, we have no problem seeing the color cyan as being both green and blue.

collapse.paragraphs: Similarly, the color sensation of yellow-versus-blue is also processed antagonistically. No color is perceived as being yellowish and bluish at the same time.

Moreover, the red-green and yellow-blue channels are independent from each other. Hence, red and green are both perceived as neither yellow or blue, and yellow and blue are perceived as neither red or green.

@sep It has been proposed that an S cone stimulus contributes positively to the red-green channel. Under this proposition, it is easy to see why spectral colors towards the violet end of the visible color spectrum appears reddish.

Moreover, this explains why, perceptually, it appears natural to wrap the visible hue spectrum into a color wheel, with magenta serving as the link between violet and red.

(Food for thought: there is no magenta on the rainbow.)

slide.paragraphs: In an opponent process model, our perception of color is established via comparison. This may explain some of the color illusions which result when we place colors of different hues or lightness adjacent to each other, e.g. a neutral grey appearing pinkish next to a greenish blue color.
It also explains the illusion of complementary
, where, for example, someone having stared at a red color for a long time who then suddenly looks upon a white sheet might see a green color.

blockquote.paragraphs: If you mean to represent great darkness, it must be done by contrasting it with great light; on the contrary, if you want to produce great brightness, you must oppose to it a very dark shade : so a pale yellow will cause red to appear more beautiful than if opposed to a purple colour.

There is another rule, by observing which, though you do not increase the natural beauty of the colours, yet by bringing them together they may give additional grace to each other, as green placed near red, while the effect would be quite the reverse, if placed near blue.

slide.paragraphs: In the context of trichromatic color theory, an object's color is dependent upon the the color of the light which illuminates it. For example, a red apple lit by a blue light should appear purple.

p.paragraphs: However, it appears that the brain has a built-in mechanism to filter out lighting conditions and interpret (unconsciously) the "true" color of an object.
